newsitem.title: USA: Tandem unveils nonstop database for NT.
newsitem.headline: Tandem unveils nonstop database for NT.

text.p: Tandem Computers Inc on Wednesday unveiled database software that will let companies store huge amounts of vital information on a network of cheap computers running Microsoft Corp's Windows NT.
The Tandem software, dubbed Nonstop Sequel MX Database, divides a library of corporate information, such as customer or inventory lists, among up to 16 Windows NT server computers.
But the software coordinates the functions of the 16 machines to operate as if they were one, speeding up searches, Tandem said.
Until now, giant databases had to be stored on relatively expensive mainframe computers or servers based on the Unix software standard.
Tandem, based in Cupertino, California, specialises in making computers and hardware that never shut off and can handle massive amount of transactions.
Some of the world's biggest banks, telephone companies and stock exchanges rely on its fail-safe products to run their businesses.
But the company's sales have been declining for the past two years as some of its traditional customers have set up information systems using networks of cheap PCs.

The new database software is part of the company's strategy to use the popularity of Microsoft's Window NT networking software to get a jump on competitors, such as International Business Machines Corp and Oracle Corp, said Bill Heil, Tandem senior vice president.
"The people that are successful in the software industry have been able to get their products out early" as new standards emerge, Heil said.

He said Dayton Hudson Corp, owner of the retailing chain Target, will demonstrate on Wednesday that standard PC servers -- tied together with Tandem software and running Tandem's new database -- can handle Target's giant library of inventory and price information.
